Have you read all the original discussions and agreements made on that review?

I tried to cover as much as possible to reflect the discussed points inside my implementation. The two agreements I found in the discussion, are #1 the agreement on how to handle the legacy systemName "system" for the time being and #2 the way on how to gradually implement multi host, which you have clarified very well. Is there another agreement I have missed?
I just wanted to make sure you had the context on past attempts;  There wasn't anything specific i was eluding to.
Acknowledged

Please read and understand the existing way we handle multiple items in a collection.  Some of this is documented in DBUS_USAGE.md  Collections are generally built by walking objects of the correct type, then parsing the leaf node, and using that within the URI.  This is such a common pattern that we have the getCollectionMembers method specifically for this purpose.

Doing this gives users the ability to set their own URI strings to within the limits of redfish, without bmcweb having to take an opinion on naming.  This is an important design consideration that needs added.

I understand, I made the wrong assumption here. I will change this, so the intended design is met. 
However, the current implementation is not using the getCollectionMembers method, instead we are hardcoding the member URI "/redfish/v1/Systems/system". If I would  use getCollectionMembers, currently the only reliable way to get multiple hosts is via the xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host interface, which for single host would return the leaf node "host0". This in turn, would end up naming the member URI on single host "/redfish/v1/Systems/host0". Should I consider this breaking the single host implementation?

> currently the only reliable way to get multiple hosts

Right, we need to make it reliable to get hosts from DBus as a prerequisite for this patch.
Acknowledged

Please read and understand the coding standard.  You've done a number of things that we've found to be anti patterns, the most important of which is creating very long lambdas by taking existing code and wrapping it in a lambda.  Rather than that, generally we would recommend taking the code in question and putting it in a normal method.

It looks like you don't have a CLA set up, so take a look at the docs folder on how to set that up.

Please run your patch through CI;  There are several failures.

Also, this is very likely to conflict with my patch here https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/71484;  We'll deal with that as it comes up, but just be aware of it.

I guess CI will be available, once my user account got approval?

Thank you for pointing this out!

Hello Ed, thank you for your reply. I will take care of it! 

As for the CLA, I had trouble adding my company mail address to my gerrit account, which probably will resolve the issue. Who can I contact to help me with my account settings? It probably is due to the fact that I changed my github handle a few months ago, however my old handle is still occupying the mail address in gerrit, thus blocking my new handle to use that mail address.
Ideally you should be running it locally on your machine before you push, so you don't have to wait for jenkins, and you can fix the failures faster.

You work for 9elements, correct?  It looks like your admins are
Alexander Hansen
Arthur Heymans
Marvin Drees
Patrick Rudolph
Patrik Tesarik

Looks like a gerrit bug, so it would need to be resolved by someone with access to the gerrit database. I'm not sure what i could do about it.

If his old github handle does not exist, and the only login for that account is via github, then the login is not possible and the account may be inaccessible. It makes sense for that account to be deleted then, or to at least release the email from it.

Who has access to these gerrit internals to kindly help resolve this issue?

I can help remove the old email from the gerrit database if needed although it looks like you just added the new email to https://gerrit.openbmc.org/admin/groups/28c6457ee3c81a1c4b54a07d8fe4b5f3eff9778e,members which works just as well.

Hi Andrew, although I am now verified for CI and technically everything works just fine, I would prefer to signoff my commits wiht my company mail address in the future. This currently does fail at the point I try to push my commit with a signoff that is not assigned to my account. It would be great if you could help me fix this! My old handle was olekatpyle. Is there anything else you need to know?
I'm closing this out;  There are multiple avenues to communicate with gerrit admins (I suspect andrew prefers discord or email), I will assume the two of you will work that out.

What is an "ObjectMapper state" object?

A xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host object?

xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host works fine for power control, which is all this implements, but doesn't really work beyond that.  For a case that immediately breaks this, look at post codes.  We very likely wouldn't answer the question "Does this host have post code support" by looking up the power state parameter.

> System discovery via the inventory seems to be problematic

I think the answer here is to fix system discovery via inventory, not try to invent another one.  I don't see that scaling beyond this patch.

Sorry for the vague expression, but yes I mean xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host. In general, the only reason we are looking at the state paths currently is to retrieve a valid index of existing hosts, that we can use to validate the requested systemName and later construct our dbus object_paths with the found index. I.e "/xyz/openbmc_project/control/host+index/auto_reboot".


In general, I agree on system discovery via dbus being fixed in order to use for expample getCollectionMembers from collection_util instead of having a custom solution is the correct way of doing this, but that requires a good discussion on how to achieve it and probably some time to be adapted. I am very open for that, what do you suggest on how to start the discussion properly? @Patrick Williams what are your thoughts on this topic?

As of now, this implementation tries to be a working starting point for multi-host platforms.

> Sorry for the vague expression, but yes I mean xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host. In general, the only reason we are looking at the state paths currently is to retrieve a valid index of existing hosts, that we can use to validate the requested systemName and later construct our dbus object_paths with the found index. I.e "/xyz/openbmc_project/control/host+index/auto_reboot".

Yep, I understand.

> 
> 
> In general, I agree on system discovery via dbus being fixed in order to use for expample getCollectionMembers from collection_util instead of having a custom solution is the correct way of doing this, but that requires a good discussion on how to achieve it and probably some time to be adapted. I am very open for that, what do you suggest on how to start the discussion properly? @Patrick Williams what are your thoughts on this topic?

Probably start by looking up the last couple times we've talked about exactly this 😊. I believe the last discussion was on the mailing list.  There's also several discussions on gerrit.

> 
> As of now, this implementation tries to be a working starting point for multi-host platforms.

Cool, in that case please mark it WIP if you don't intend this patch to be merged.  It helps to keep things organized.

No, my intention is to get this feature merged. However I understand your remarks on the current implementation / design. 
I also got informed about the development in phosphor-dbus-interfaces that should solve the problems (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/72414). Once it gets merged I will continue on this patch and rework the design accordingly.

> No, my intention is to get this feature merged.

Cool, then lets get the coding issues sorted.

> However I understand your remarks on the current implementation / design. 
> I also got informed about the development in phosphor-dbus-interfaces that should solve the problems (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/72414). Once it gets merged I will continue on this patch and rework the design accordingly.

Sounds good.
Done
Not true.
Oh I see my error, I read the date the european way which ends up being read as 9th January. Thinking about it, that would be a rather specific date to remove an option flag.
For systems generated from DBus, this really should be coming from dbus.  The option flag that existed was only for when bmcweb is selecting the name.
Could you elaborate this?

reading the getCollectionMembers code can answer your question a lot better than I can.  ComputerSystemCollection should ideally use that same helper method to generate the URI the exact same way we handle it for other collections.

The overall intent is that in the end I don't want bmcweb in charge of naming things.  We already get it wrong in the case of "system" and "bmc", which is why we have to configure it.
Acknowledged
Reopening until this is resolved in code.
Done

What if I wanted to name my system

redfish_1_system


That wouldn't be possible, which is why we try to get URI names from dbus when we can, keeping bmcweb out of the loop.  Please take a look at the getCollectionMembers method.  Ideally we'd be able to use that as is for the computer system collection, or something very similar.

I don't see why that wouldn't be possible. This implementation doesn't care about what the set uri name is. Using your example, a user on multi-host would request via uri /redfish/v1/Systems/redfish_1_system1 to get the resources of host 1 and /redfish/v1/Systems/redfish_1_system2 to get to the resources of host 2. 
Should this behavior be changed?
" the index is appended to it:" could be rephrased as "the index is appended to the end of it" so in this model I wouldn't be able to add a system index in the middle.
Acknowledged

Ah, now I see my confusion.  It says here that it followed TESTING.md, but that we're ignoring the failing result.

Systems with multihost enabled currently pass.  For features that are ready for master, we should not regress from passing to failing.

Feel free to use the existing option flag to shut off the paths to any URLs that don't currently pass when in multihost mode, but considering we haven't written multi-host specific tests yet, redfish-service-validator is the best tool we have for finding failures and I would expect it to pass.
Acknowledged

Then omit the failing URLs when we're on a system index > 1.  This is what was talked about in the past, and I think gives the best result.

The code as it exists passes the tests.  We shouldn't regress from passing to failing.
If I understand correctly, for future testing I should run the validator with the --payload flag and only test routes I know will succeed and for as long as the other headers haven't been adapted?

Redfish is a hypermedia tree.  The agreement we had in the past was that URIs that had been ported to multihost would be returned, and URIs that hadn't been ported to multihost would be omitted from the hypermedia tree so that:
A. tests will pass.
B. It's very obvious to a user which URIs should be expected to work on a multihost system.
Acknowledged

I see lots of URIS in this result that haven't been changed to handle multi-system in this patch, so it's surprising that Redfish service validator is passing, and I have no idea how redfish is giving the correct result.  In this code, I would expect most of the sub URLs to 404.

I would expect that in this patch, sub URLs that haven't been moved over to the new system,
/redfish/v1/Systems/<str>/LogServices for example, would be omitted from the response.

It's also possible there's a bug in service validator.  Can you post your passing report somewhere, or take a look and determine if you in fact found a bug in service validator?

As mentioned above, redfish validator fails for yv4. The confusion might come from patchset 2, where I stated that rf validator succeeded on yv4. This however was more likely due to the implementation of getComputerSystemIndex.
ACK

Lots of coding standard violations here.  You might want to familiarize yourself with COMMON_ERRORS.md, as well as 
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/857060209ef5e3bef0fe5b5e6dd40cf1b55a8c20/anti-patterns.md?plain=1#L1
Generally these would return a dbus path to be used in later operations, not an index.  An index ties us to a specific naming convention, which we should avoid.

As I see it, there is a naming convention for dbus object_paths including indices. That is why we try to find out the index of the requested system in order to construct the correct object_paths in later operations.
Yep, lets close this out in the other thread;  We have a mechanism for handling dbus collections -> redfish.  We should be following it.
Acknowledged
Reopening until this is resolved in code.
Done

I still see an int index passed in the current patchset, not a dbus path.  In the future, rather than just marking things "done" please give a short description of what you actually did to resolve the issue.
Ack. Almost obsolete now, since we return dbus paths in upcoming patch.
Common error.  Please read and understand COMMON_ERRORS.md
I guess you are referring to imprecise string matching? This is true if we look at the line isolated, but looking at the function as a whole, we end up matching precisely I would think.

That's one thing, using exceptions for non exceptional paths (line 181) is another, non trivial lambdas (line 161) is a third.

I just assumed that you hadn't read that yet.
Acknowledged
Once you think you've brought this patchset up to the coding standard, feel free to close this out and I'll re-review with more specifics if there's anything remaining.
Done
Reopening, as there are still instances of this present in the current patchset.
Ack. As mentioned before, no such if-statement exists in the upcoming patch.
Acknowledged
Reopening until this is resolved in code.  Please close once the code is fixed.
Done
Why does this route through getComputerSystemIndex if we then ignore the result?
This was a mistake from my side, the index needs to be used when constructing the object_path.

Can we break this patchset down to JUST the changes to make ComputerSystemCollection work for the moment?  I think that will give the best result, so we can get agreement on what the general interfaces are before we start porting things.

Partial review as last round of comments seem to have just been marked done without actually having been done or understood.

In the future, lets have a short sentence response on what you did to update the patch in the response to the comments rather than just marking "done".  I think that'll help us communicate better.



In addition, lets break this patchset down to JUST the ComputerSystemCollection changes, so we can do this incrementally over time, rather than trying to get the whole power reset case handled in one patch.

Would also like to see IBM review to see if this would work for their hypervisor use cases, so we can clean up that code.  @Asmitha, @Andrew,is that something you can do or find someone with knowledge of how the IBM hypervisor stuff works?

Sure, I will do this in the future. 

I have now splited the commit to only include the introduction of getCollectionMembers in systems.hpp aswell as adjusted the commit message. I am working on resolving the issues you have commented here in a new patch. Will publish those under the same topic once I have fixed them. Is that ok with you?
That sounds great.  Thank you for accommodating me.
Done

Please don't capture request objects by value.  They make VERY large copies.  Parse out the information you need in the first callback for a given flow.

FYI, we're trying to make this pitfall more obvious here:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/71547

Under the hope that we can catch this earlier.
Ack. Working on parsing out the reqParams in the upcoming patch.
std::move.
Ack. Using move in upcoming patch.
mutable
Ack. Not constant anymore in upcoming patch.
Instance of common error #12 https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/71547
Ack. Removed if statement alltogether.

Please don't make whitespace changes that are unrelated to your logic change.  They make this patchset hard to review.  There are multiple, I will let you find them clean them up rather than marking all of them.
Ack. clang-format did some weirdness there. Local ci now applying correct format.

BMCWEB_EXPERIMENTAL_REDFISH_MULTI_COMPUTER_SYSTEM is not the same as BMCWEB_REDFISH_SYSTEM_URI_NAME.empty().  They are different parameters for different purposes.  Just leaving the System URI empty does not explicitly enable multi host, and as written, can lead to systems that don't work.


Do we have an understanding of why this branch needs to remain here at all?

I would expect some logic like:

Build the collection
If there is only one member, have the collection name match BMCWEB_REDFISH_SYSTEM_URI_NAME

I understand, I went back to using BMCWEB_EXPERIMENTAL_REDFISH_MULTI_COMPUTER_SYSTEM then.

The reason I branch here, is because non of the single host machines configure the ManagedHost interface as of now, which getCollecdtionMembers bases the search on. As I understand we would break single host if we don't branch like this, since the call to getCollectionMembers would not return any system on single host. I agree however, once every single host system implements the ManagedHost interface, the branching will no longer be needed.

> I understand, I went back to using BMCWEB_EXPERIMENTAL_REDFISH_MULTI_COMPUTER_SYSTEM then.
> 
> The reason I branch here, is because non of the single host machines configure the ManagedHost interface as of now, which getCollecdtionMembers bases the search on.
> As I understand we would break single host if we don't branch like this, since the call to getCollectionMembers would not return any system on single host. I agree however, once every single host system implements the ManagedHost interface, the branching will no longer be needed.


Right, and my understanding and the agreement I had with others when we talked about this option was that we were going to fix that ahead of merging this patch, and make single host systems have something on DBus we could key off, so that ComputerSystemCollection worked the same as all other dbus collections.  Then, one at a time, we would slowly remove the places where the option was used.

Alright. I tried to implement the logic you suggested in your initial comment, but checking the count after the collection has been build fails, due to getCollectionMembers running async and the value not being set in time. I don't see another way to get the count, other than reading it from the json in the response object. The branching would fix this at least. Should I overload getCollectionMembers to be able to run a callback inside of it? What do you suggest?

> Alright. I tried to implement the logic you suggested in your initial comment, but checking the count after the collection has been build fails, due to getCollectionMembers running async and the value not being set in time.
> I don't see another way to get the count, other than reading it from the json in the response object. The branching would fix this at least. Should I overload getCollectionMembers to be able to run a callback inside of it? What do you suggest?



Why do you need to "check the count" async?  getCollectionMembers builds the whole collection.

Maybe push the code that you think is correct that isn't working, and we can take a look?  It's hard to debug code we can't see.

> > Alright. I tried to implement the logic you suggested in your initial comment, but checking the count after the collection has been build fails, due to getCollectionMembers running async and the value not being set in time.
> > I don't see another way to get the count, other than reading it from the json in the response object. The branching would fix this at least. Should I overload getCollectionMembers to be able to run a callback inside of it? What do you suggest?
> 
> 
> 
> Why do you need to "check the count" async?  getCollectionMembers builds the whole collection.
> 
> Maybe push the code that you think is correct that isn't working, and we can take a look?  It's hard to debug code we can't see.

I have pushed the code, thank you for having a look!
Done
What if you have a system named "hypervisor".  Wont' this conflict?  I suspect this needs to stay under the option flag.
like: if (BMCWEB_REDFISH_MANAGER_URI_NAME != "hypervisor") and then do the hypervisor check?

Also I had a short exchange on the topic in regards to multi host with @Patrick. At the moment there are no multi host platforms using hypervisors. I suggested we just opt out of it for now entirely for multi host. Are you ok with that?

Hypervisor is different than BMCWEB_REDFISH_MANAGER_URI_NAME (which is usually bmc) they are different computersystem resources.

what does "opt out" mean?  There's no option flag for hypervisor today?  If that means to just break them, that's something you'll have to take up with the IBM folks.

FWIW, I've asked them in another thread to add an option flag for the hypervisor stuff so that this kind of thing isn't something we have to worry about;  Hopefully they reply and do that.

Also, just to set expectation, just because YOU don't have multihost + hypervisor, doesn't mean you can break the hypervisor code without discussion between you and the folks that work on that feature (which has had patches pushed in the last week, so people are still actively developing and using it).  That was the comment made above.

If your code limits itself such that single systems + hypervisor continue to work, but multihost + hypervisor doesn't, that's fine (because you're right, I don't know of any use cases) but we can't just break things.  What I was pointing out here is that we need some branch to differentiate the two modes.  I've asked gunnar in another gerrit thread to just add an option flag for this and call it good;  We'll see what happens there.

FWIW, I really wish the hypervisor stuff had never been checked in, because of the number of rules it breaks, and it hardcodes yet another ID into bmcweb, but we're here now, we need to make our best attempt to not break folks.

> Also, just to set expectation, just because YOU don't have multihost + hypervisor, doesn't mean you can break the hypervisor code without discussion between you and the folks that work on that feature (which has had patches pushed in the last week, so people are still actively developing and using it).  That was the comment made above.

Also another option would be to put the hypervisor code into the singe host handle in getSystemCollectionMembers.

-> getCollectionMembers

> If there is only one member, have the collection name match  BMCWEB_REDFISH_SYSTEM_URI_NAME

Can you please just put this under the redfish namespace, and give it a more represetative name?  handleSystemCollectionMembers.

Having two functions with the same name in different namespaces can cause confusion.
Ack. Renamed the function and removed the additional namespace.

No need to make these arguments if this is only ever building one collection.  The arguments made sense when the function was generic, but this is only handling a single collection, so everything can just be inlined in the appropriate places.
Ack. Went on to inline them.

This code also assumes that it's run synchronously.  Now that you've moved hypervisor to where its at, this code is run at the same time as the hypervisor code, so you can't just overwrite the whole array.

I suspect we can just add the hypervisor code at the end of this to get the same behavior we had before.

@Asmitha, @Andrew, would it be ok for you if we move the hypervisor code inside systems.hpp->handleComputerSystemCollectionGet into getSystemCollectionMembers, to prevent parallel execution of the code in question? Or is there anyone else I should ask?
I adapted the code to the new hypervisor option, that has been just merged. Since we also came to an agreement on relocating the hypervisor code, I close this down.

This really needs a hypervisor specific option.

Closing this, since we moved the discussion into another thread.
With your new code, you're now running this in parallel with getSystemCollectionMembers.  This is now a race between which daemon responds first (the mapper or settingsd).
More details in documentation: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/COMMON_ERRORS.md#13-complete-replacement-of-the-response-object
I guess if we come to an agreement with IBM on moving the code to getSystemCollectionMembers this would be resolved?
Lets just follow up on the other thread.  The agreement with IBM i thought would be around how the option flag was handled.  The race condition needs handled either way.

I now moved the code to fix the race condition. I also removed the option flag that guards the hypervisor code since it doesn't cut it and reverted some of the code to its initial state (renaming variables, swapping lines of code), to point out that practically only a relocation of code from the collection handler was done in this patch, to be as close as possible in line with upstream code. 
As soon as there is clarification on how to deal with the hypervisor code, I will adapt the code in this patch accordingly. 
IMO this works best for both of us having the patch technically fixed but open for change once the decision is made on how to proceed with the hypervisor code. I then could move on to push the next patch regarding multi host support to continue our  discussion on the design. What is your opinion on this?

I checked out S7106 in qemu to test this case, and I'm seeing a totally empty collection:

```
❯ curl -k --user "root:0penBmc" -N "https://192.168.7.2/redfish/v1/Systems"
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems",
  "@odata.type": "#ComputerSystemCollection.ComputerSystemCollection",
  "Members": [],
  "Members@odata.count": 0,
  "Name": "Computer System Collection"
}%
```

Is that expected?

Unless you haven't implemented the ManagedHost dbus interface this is the expected result.
